title: Case Study: Post-Lobectomy Patient with Residual Chest Pain
clinical_history: A 45-year-old male patient, 6 weeks post-right upper lobectomy for lung cancer, presents with complaints of residual chest pain and limited mobility. The surgery was performed due to a diagnosis of stage I lung adenocarcinoma. The patient has a history of smoking (20 pack-years) and has been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue since the surgery. He reports difficulty taking deep breaths and coughing, which has led to decreased physical activity.

nprs.affected_area: chest wall, incision site, and shoulder

aggrevating_factors: coughing, deep breathing, and movement of the right arm and shoulder, especially when lifting or reaching
picture: A 24-hour picture showing limited mobility, frequent use of pain medication, and difficulty sleeping due to pain
easing_factors: rest, pain medication (opioids and NSAIDs), and gentle stretching exercises
past_history: history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking-related chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
medical_history: recently completed chemotherapy and radiation therapy following the lobectomy
medications: oxycodone for pain management, inhalers for COPD, and statins for hyperlipidemia
personal_history: married with two children, works as an accountant but currently on medical leave, and has a supportive family network
imaging: post-operative chest X-ray and CT scans showing the lobectomy site and no evidence of complications or disease recurrence
